ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: No further comments

I think it would be valuable to add at least one class that deals with climate change skepticism and denial. It would be useful to read arguments presented by climate change deniers and skeptics. Understanding climate change is imperative. In addition, we need to understand what mechanisms prevent people from believing that climate change is real.
Very good instructor and useful overview of the basics of climate change mitigation and adaptation, with lots of information on international negotiation processes.

1. I really liked how interdisciplinary the readings were, the provided a good overview of the different angles and issues within the broad topic of climate change. They also went into more depth then we were able to go in class, so felt I got a lot out of the readings.2/7. The instructor's lecturing style was hard for me to follow. He moved very quickly through the slides and the lectures were very choppy. The best part of the lectures were when he was answering a student's question because then he was talking in a straight forward more conversational way rather then reading off the slides. The most useful thing about his slides were his use of graphs. The graphs in the slides were often ones used in the readings but that I didn't understand and so it was very helpful to have them explained.3. I would have liked it if instead of student led discussions of the second half of class could have included more in depth discussions/ explanations of some of the material. I would have liked to hear about the instructor's experience and heard more from him rather than overviews from the students. I think more in depth discussions would have been beneficial.
the weekly write ups on reading material, really helped with my writing and understanding of the material.
The best parts of this course were class participation (specifically student-led group discussions) and the readings.

We covered a ton of topics which was incredibly helpful for getting an overview of everything climate. Rob also did a great job of answering any questions in class (he had responses for pretty much every question, but if he didn't know an answer he would go look it up and get back to the class).
Since everyone had done the reading, it made for interesting class conversation.

The best things about this class were Rob's lectures, the policy memo, and the final paper. Rob gave great overviews of each week's topic and the two papers were a great exercise in synthesizing information of your choice about climate change and making recommendations.
The openness of the class dynamic. Every student was very welcome to participate and express their opinion.
The weekly reading responses force you to read and reflect on all of the class readings.
Great overview of a wide variety of subjects.

The breadth of material that was covered and the readings were very helpful. Also the weakly writing assignments really kept me on task with the reading and I feel that I got a lot more out of the readings because of that assignment (I think they should be due later though for example 12:00am the night before class).

Professor Bailis has very extensive knowledge of climate science and policy. The readings were, in general, very interesting and informative, and the lectures were clear and engaging. An excellent overview of climate change.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Slow down a little and maybe cover a little less material.
The lectures seem a little rushed sometimes, but maybe this is just the nature of an introductory course on such an enormous issue.

Get rid of the student led discussions at the end of class. They were extremely boring and not interesting at all. The length of the class was also problematic, three hours is a long time to make students sit through a powerpoint presentation. It would have been cool if other teaching tools could have been used instead of massive powerpoint presentations. I also would have appreciated if Rob coordinated more with the students before their student-led discussions. He would post the powerpoint presentation the day of lecture, so students couldn't see what he was going to cover in his lecture or know what they needed to include or not include in their discussion as a result.

Writing a commentary every week can become tedious, but at least it forces you to do the reading. Some of the student led discussions were a bit drab. I would grade the discussions and let students know their grades as the semester continues. Additionally, I would let students know what grade they are receiving on their commentaries.
It could have been interesting to have class presentations of students´final papers.

Many of the student-led discussions fell flat. At the beginning of the semester, Rob and the TAs stressed the value of leading engaging discussions, but students should be prodded throughout the remainder of the semester to keep the discussions engaging and relevant. One of the best things about this class is that everyone has read the material and formulated an opinion. It was disappointing when "discussions" were powerpoint presentations of what we'd all read before class.
None, the course was great.

The lecturing style of the professor. I would also suggest that maybe every other week the professor would lead the discussion and every other week would be led by the students. If discussions were led by the professor than the discussions could go deeper and I think I would have gotten more out of the material.

Some of the readings were very long and technical. Also, the second half of each lecture was dedicated to student presentations. These were not nearly as informative as Bailis's lectures. While presenting is a worthwhile experience, watching the presentations was not always a great use of time.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: very good.
The TAs were very responsive to inquiry, and Professor Bailis offered valuable insight on term-paper proposals/concepts.
The instructor and TAs did not get back to me right away, but they did respond within a few days.
The instructor and TAs were always available and gave excellent assistance.
Excellent. Great job Dan Berkman.
Both the instructor and TAs provided useful feedback.
The TAs were great and active in class. Well done!
Very good, exceeded my expectations
Great. Rob and the TAs were very responsive. It's amazing that they were able to send comments back on every reading response.
Good on all accounts, although the instructor has short office hour meeting times (per student).

One of the TAs (Dan Burkman) was very helpful. He always responded to my emails very promptly and helped me find sources for my paper.The professor was available but when I met with him he seemed a bit distracted.

Professor Bailis is not always available because he travels and seems to be in great demand from F&ES students. I imagine that getting a slot in his office hours can be more challenging than for most professors. However, he was quick to respond to questions I e-mailed to him, and he always informed the class about when he would be

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I found it very helpful, I think an understanding of climate change is essential for environmental management today.
It definitely fits into my overall program because I am interested in climate.
Climate change relates to everything, especially water resource management.

This course fit into my program by giving me a great foundation in the latest policies, impacts, adaptation, and mitigation strategies for climate change. I wanted to be informed about what was going on regarding climate change in all of these aspects. This course gave a great basis in all of this.
Climate Change is a key topic in my overall program, so this course was very relevant.
I think it's pretty important to have a good understanding of various aspects of climate change no matter what kind of work we go on to do.
The subject matter is very helpful and this course does a good job for students interested in the interdisciplinary nature of climate change.
I'm very interested in international environmental governance and American environmental politics, so this course was a great fit.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I found it interesting.
To gain a better understanding of the fundamental social and scientific principles of climate change.
I wanted to get an overview of all the climate topics since I will be workingin the climate field in the future.
To learn more about climate change and its impacts on water resources.
I took this course to get a foundation in climate change impacts, adaptation, mitigation, and policies.
Because the instructor is my advisor and I wanted to have a direct learning contact with him. Climate Change is key to my interest.
I wanted more than a basic understanding of climate change. I anticipate future employers will expect as much.
Knew little about the subject and wanted a more detailed overview than reading the New York Times.
Because the subject matter interests me and I would like to work on climate change issues in my career.
I took this course because I wanted an overview of climate impacts and policies, which is exactly what I got.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: yes.
Absolutely. A wonderful course.
Yes.
yes
Yes. Although the first few classes should be a bit more of an general overview of climate change for folks that have no prior knowledge.
Yes.
Yes. This course taught me about climate change and I practiced making recommendations to a business in the memo assignment.
Yes
Yes.
Yes.
yes in that I learned a lot, and no in that I felt dissatisfied with the actual class time.
Yes, this class was just as good as I hope it would be.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes.
Yes.
Yes.
yes
Yes.
Yes.
Yes
Yes
Yes, perfectly.
yes, I just wish I could remember it all.
Yes, this course gave me the foundational understanding of climate change that I hoped for.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantages = get to split up the readings and the work. Disadvantages = trying to coordinate different schedules and work styles.
The discussion sessions had a group work component at times. This was helpful to hear everyone's perspectives.
N/A
it was a very small part of the class so I don't feel that it was either good or bad.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: stay focused during class, it moves quickly and a lot of information is covered.

Put a good deal of thought into your final paper. It's a great opportunity to explore whichever aspect(s) of climate change is (are) most pertinent to your area of interest with input from one of the world's foremost climate/energy experts.

If you're interested in climate, take this class. There is a ridiculous amount of reading and the group-led discussions are incredibly painful, but the class will give you a great overview of all the most relevant climate topics.
Enjoy the readings.

This is a great course to take if you want to get a foundation in climate change impacts, policies, mitigation, and adaptation. Rob gives good solid lectures using slides and the discussions help to mix things up a bit. The two papers are a great opportunity to focus in on what you're interested in regarding climate change. The readings are great and help give you all the current info out there on climate change. Great course!
To prepare for lots of reading and writing weekly papers
This is a great class and a great way to learn about many aspects of climate change. There's a hefty amount of reading involved.

Take it! The workload is manageable and you'll learn a lot. Think early about the topic of your research paper, and make it the focus of your policy memo as well, so that you can go deeper into the topic.
